repository.corpname: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

did.unittitle: Primary Writing small press records and Phyllis Rosenzweig personal correspondence collection
did.physloc: Materials are stored off-site, and will require additional retrieval time. Please contact the Special Collections Research Center for more information.
did.abstract:
This collection contains publications (journal issues, postcards, monographs) related to the Primary Writing publication as well as small presses in Washington D.C., manuscript drafts, correspondence both related to the journal publication and other Primary Writing related work between Phyllis Rosenzweig, Diane Ward, and contributing authors, and a small amount of organization records related to the production of a journal including layout mock-ups, and receipts. There is also a series with correspondence between Phyllis Rosenzweig and writers that cover topics beyond Primary Writing. These records date from 1973-2019 with the bulk of the records dating between 1994-2009.
Primary Writing was a small press publication devoted to work by contemporary poets in the D.C. area, New York, the West Coast and beyond. Co-edited by Diane Ward and Phyllis Rosenzweig, it consists of 44 issues published between April 1995 and February 2008. The issues varied in format from postcard, to broadside, to stapled booklet, depending on the content of each one, and were mailed to an extended audience of writers and special collection libraries.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Materials in this collection are governed by copyright. For activities that the researcher determines fall under fair use as defined under U. S. Copyright Law, no permission to cite or publish is required. Researchers are responsible for determining who may hold materials' copyrights, determining if the intended re-use falls under fair use, and obtaining approval from the copyright holder if the intended use does not fall under fair use. Please contact Special Collections if the copyright status of the materials you wish to reuse is unclear. Staff will provide additional information.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Please cite unpublished materials in the following way:
Please provide the title and date of item, catalog number (if applicable it will be found written on the folder), name of the collection, name of the repository, and location of the repository.

Example: James Oglethorpe to the Trustees, 13 January 1876, RG0001 Series 1, Box 4, Folder 3. Records of the Board of Trustees, Special Collections Research Center, Gelman Library, The George Washington University, Washington, D.C.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into four series: Publications and correspondence, Phyllis Rosenzweig personal correspondence with writers, DC small press publications, and Doug Lang correspondence and publications

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: With this donation came issues of the journal Washington Review. After weeding out duplicates the remaining issues were added to the serial holdings in Special Collections. The issues included from this accession are v. 9 no. 1 - no. 4, v. 10 no. 2 - no. 3, v. 13 no. 2. The call no. for this publication is NX 510.W3 W32.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains publications (journal issues, postcards, monographs) related to the Primary Writing publication as well as small presses in Washington D.C., manuscript drafts, correspondence both related to the journal publication and other Primary Writing related work between Phyllis Rosenzweig, Diane Ward, and contributing authors, and a small amount of organization records related to the production of a journal including layout mock-ups, and receipts. There is also a series with correspondence between Phyllis Rosenzweig and writers that cover topics beyond Primary Writing. These records date from 1973-2019 with the bulk of the records dating between 1994-2009.

bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: Phyllis Rosenzweig is curator emerita of the Hirshhorn Museum & Sculpture Garden. She has also taught adjunct classes at GWU and the Corcoran College of Art + Design, and organized several exhibitions of contemporary art in D.C. and the Bronx, New York. She affiliates herself with a group of D.C. poets (including Tina Darragh, Lynne Dreyer, Peter Inman, Diane Ward, Bernard Welt, and Terence Winch), and a community originally formed around Folio Bookstore and readings organized there by poet Doug Lang in the 1970s. She currently edits Primary Writing Books, devoted to publishing work by D.C. area writers.

bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: Poet Diane Ward (November 9, 1956- ) was born in Washington, DC and attended the Corcoran School of Art. She was initially associated with the first wave of Language poetry in the 1970s. She has published more than a dozen works of poetry and been included in numerous anthologies.

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: Primary Writing was a small press publication devoted to work by contemporary poets in the D.C. area, New York, the West Coast and beyond. Co-edited by Diane Ward and Phyllis Rosenzweig, it consists of 44 issues published between April 1995 and February 2008. The issues varied in format from postcard, to broadside, to stapled booklet, depending on the content of each one, and were mailed to an extended audience of writers and special collection libraries. Three issues of an earlier version of Primary Writing were published by Phyllis Rosenzweig in 1983, 1984, and 1988.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains correspondence, published issues of Primry Writing, monographs, and manuscripts. Primary Writing ceased publication as a periodical in 2007. In 2011 Phyllis Rosenzweig began publishing Primary Writing Books, books and chapbooks of writing by D.C. area authors. Six, of a projected 10, have been printed so far. This correspondence is specifically related to Primary Writing.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arrangement maintained the original order created by the donor.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Note provided by the donor: One copy of each issue of Primary Writing, the small press magazine published by Phyllis Rosenzweig and Diane Ward (then living in Los Angeles). Formats vary from postcard to several pages. Includes complete index; also copy attached separately.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Note provided by the donor: Miscellaneous receipts for printing, etc.; paper samples, etc.

odd.p: Note provided by the donor: Miscellaneous correspondence with subscribers

odd.head: General
odd.p: Note provided by the donor: Many versions of mailing list (issues mailed out for free) and notes for revisions as names are added, deleted, addresses change or issues are returned without forwarding addresses

odd.head: General
odd.p: Note provided by the donor: The original, earlier, iteration of Primary Writing published only by Phyllis Rosenzweig, conceived as single issues each devoted to one long work by an individual writer. Only three issues were published: #1"Via Negativa" by Jane DeLynn, 1983, 22 pp.stapled, #2 "3 Novels" by Doug Lang, 1988, 18 pp. stapled.* #2 "3 Novels" by Doug Lang, 1988, 18 pp. stapled.*
*Originally projected to be #2 but was delayed so was preceded by #3.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Note provided by the donor: Primary Writing ceased publication as a periodical in 2007. In 2011 Phyllis Rosenzweig began publishing Primary Writing Books, books and chapbooks of writing by D.C. area authors. Six, of a projected 10, have been printed so far. One copy of each are included here. They are: Phyllis Rosenzweig. Girls (2012), Doug Lang. dÃ©rangÃ© (2012)* *This book is out of print and very rare. Very few copies exist, Ken Jacobs. Unmet (2012), Lynne Dreyer. The Under Arc (2015), Cathy Eisenhower. animalitos (2017), Chris Mason. Some of the Methods of Performing Poetry Employed in and Around Baltimore from the Late 60's to the Early Teens by Poets in Their Late Teens to Early 60's (2019)

did.unittitle: Phyllis Rosenzweig personal correspondence with writers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains correspondence between Phyllis Rosenzweig and numerous D.C. writers. In many instances a folder also contains original manuscripts. This personal correspondence does include some of the same people as in Series 1 and related to Primary Writing, but in this series the correspondence is more general and far ranging.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arrangement maintained the original order created by the donor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains publications, monographs and magazine, of small presses located in Washington DC as well as drafts, notes, and correspondence for the publication Intraview which was intended for inclusion in an issue of The Difficulties. The material dates from 1973-1988.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
List of publications:
Jim Brodey. Unless, Jawbone, 1977. Jawbone Press was edited by Doug Lang
Tina Darragh. Exposed Faces. A.BACUS No. 4 (July 1984)
P. Inman, U.S.A., Dry Imager Publications, 1975. Prose. Cover by Doug Lang.
P. Inman. Backbite. A.BACUS No. 1 (January 1984)
P. Inman. Waver. A.BACUS No. 18 (May 1, 1986)
P. Inman. Uneven Development, Jimmy's House of Knowledge, 1984. Cover by Rebecca Levenson. Inscription to Phyllis Rosenzweig
Doug Lang. Horror Vacui. Hot Bird Mfg (ed. Ray DiPalma), v.1, no.18 (April 1991)
Diane Ward. Text for "Beating A Wooden Fish," for an installation by Tad Wanveer, Washington Project for the Arts, December 4-29, 1979
Terence Winch. Rooms. Hot Bird Mfg (ed. Ray DiPalma), v.1, no.1 (February 1991). Inscribed to Phyllis Rosenzweig

Titanic Books Publications: Titanic Books was edited by Terence Winch, Bernard Welt, Diane Ward and Doug Lang
Kenward Elmslie. The Alphabet Work. Titanic Books, 1977. Includes portrait of the author by Alex Katz
Ted Greenwald. Native Land, Titanic Books, 1977. Includes photo of the author by Andy Grundberg
Michael Lally. In the Mood, Titanic Books, 1978. Includes photo of the author by John Gossage

EEL For (Summer 1977), ed. P Inman, with Tina Darragh, P. Inman, Doug Lang, Diane Ward et al.) Mass Transit: A Magazine of D.C. Poets, No. 1 (Summer 1973), No. 2 (Fall-Winter 1973), No. 3 (January 1974), No. 4 (Spring-Summer1974; various issues include Tim Dlugos, Lynne Dreyer, P. Inman, Michael Lally, Bernard Welt, Terence Winch, et al.); Flyer for Mass Transit and Some of Us Press publication
The Thursday Book: Selected Poetry from the Dove Readings , Jun 1975. Includes Tina Darragh, Tim Dlugos, P. Inman, Michael Lally, Terence Winch et al.

did.unittitle: "Intraview"(1988),+ between Tina Darragh, Lynne Dreyer, Joan Retallack, and Phyllis Rosenzweig

odd.head: General
odd.p: Note provided by the donor: This was initiated by Joan Retallack in response to a request from Tom Beckett for contributions to an intended issue of The Difficulties devoted to writers' interviews (never published); drafts, notes and correspondence, 1985-88, from prior meetings of the four of us at Joan Retallack's house; a copy of a draft sent from Tina to Phyllis, of a paper by Charles Bernstein on Ezra Pound, delivered at MLA conference, Washington, DC,12/29/1984. *"Intraview" is referred to in Ann Vickery. Leaving Lines of Gender: A Feminist Genealogy of Language Writing (Hanover and London: Wesleyan University Press, 2000), 24.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series are something of a mini-archive containing correspondence, original publications of early work, and unpublished texts. Doug Lang is an influential poet and the catalyst for the formation of a close-knit community of writers in and around D.C. and beyond. A more complete archive of his work is housed in the John Jay Burns Library, Boston College, Chestnut Hill, MA.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arrangement maintained the original order created by the donor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Note from donor: Miscellaneous correspondence from and about Doug Lang; reviews of his book, DÃ©rangÃ© by Mike Zito and Terence Winch; typescript of "The Great Dismal Swamp" by Doug Lang, published in OR, Fall 2003; original typescript of "So Jah She" a collaboration between Doug Lang, Rebecca Levenson and Diane Ward, 12/27/81 for P.R.; original typescript of "Too Marvelous for Words" by Doug Lang (nd) inscribed to Phyllis Rosenzweig; photo of Doug Lang by Mary Swift; photo by Doug Lang (?) of Phyllis Rosenzweig and Terence Winch, and Tad Wanveer and Bernard Welt [Mary Swift was the co-editor of Washington Review of the Arts, for which many of us wrote; Becky Levenson, a painter, was Doug's long-time girlfriend; Tad Wanveer, a sculptor, was Diane Ward's boyfriend; Diane Ward, Bernard Welt, and Terence Winch are poets whose correspondence is elsewhere in these files];typescript for "dÃ©rangÃ©"; typescript of Doug Lang's graduation speech for the Corcoran class of 1981; syllabus for Doug Lang's Corcoran class, "History of Recorded Jazz," February 1982,with scribbled notes by Phyllis Rosenzweig; typescript of "Kendall Buster and the Expanding Universe of American Art," (1983?) published in Washington Review of the Arts (?); photocopy of "Orwell: 1984 and 1984: The Future Arrives," by Doug Lang in Review, November-December 1983; announcements and a brochure with an essay by Doug Lang for ACE exhibitions, a series of artist organized exhibitions in a former t-shirt warehouse, c.1983 (?); press release by Doug Lang [unsigned] for an exhibition of photographs by Sandra Rottmann at the Embassy of Peru, November 1999; announcement of and texts by Phyllis Rosenzweig and Diane Ward for Doug Lang's retirement celebration, May 1, 2013; typescript of "Daphne's Delight" (?) (nd) short fiction by Doug Lang; typescripts of "Karma Sestina," "Formal Sestina," and "Domestic Sestina," published in Primary Writing #10, 4/97(April 1997); c. 25 pages of typed and Xeroxed unpublished poems, and one short story, by Doug Lang; critical essay,"P. Inman U.S.A. /The Poetics of Defamiliarization" (n.d.).

c.separatedmaterial:
Separated MaterialsNote from donor:
Published work by Doug Lang, many mimeographed and published in very small press editions and locally distributed:
Doug Lang: an emblamatic life of universal dimensions: 7 postcards for Diane Ward.(published as Hot Shot, see below).
Hot Shot,for Diane Ward (Jawbone), 1977
Magic Fire Chevrolet (Titanic Books), 1980, and review of it by Art Lange, in Washington Review of the Arts, 7/3, October-November 1981. MFC includes: Sizzle; MacDonald, Pa.; Tom Raworth X's Out a Few; The Depression; Chemical Life; Love & Meat; Nerves; 333; Out of Nowhere; The Body of Con Ed; Buddha Ha-ha; Cubop City; The Language of Love; The Americans; October Moon; Xa; Lester Leaps Out; and Ozone Park.
Lumbering & Tingling: Sonnets. Self-published. (Bard 1989): Ipanema Sonnet; Formica Sonnet; Corinna Sonnet; Melancholia Sonnet; MICA Sonnet; 2 Sonnets, for Glynis & Liz;2 Sonnets, for Joan & Elaine.
Horror Vacui (To Corinna Heumann). Self-published, 1991. Visual texts.
Metro Text. For Tad Wanveer. Self-published, n.d.: Milk Duds, for Ted Greenwald; Memphis, for Phyllis Rosenzweig; D.C. (Is this your dog?); CafÃ© (I don't want to go there/There are people there/ I don't want to see there); Atomic Sonnet; Bridge in the Rain, Kimono, Face, and Blue Life, for Lyn Hejinian, with Diane Ward; Metro Text; Hard Times, for Terence Winch,; and two illustrations. In blue plastic folder.
